<QuestionSource url="https://www.ncaa.com/march-madness-live/bracket">
**Disclaimer:** The extracted content from this NCAA.com article is largely navigational/structural website content (menus, links, sport listings, etc.) rather than substantive editorial content about the 2026 March Madness bracket or tournament results. Very little meaningful tournament-specific information was captured in the extraction.

---

## Summary

The article is the **official NCAA bracket page for March Madness** hosted on NCAA.com. Based on the extracted content, the page serves as a hub for:

- **Live bracket viewing** for both the Division I Men's Basketball Tournament (March Madness Live) and the Women's tournament
- **Interactive features** such as "My Picks" and bracket challenge tools (Men's and Women's Bracket Challenge)
- **Navigation links** to scores, tickets, and merchandise related to March Madness

The only concrete scheduling details visible in the extraction reference:
- **First Four®**: March 17–18
- **Final Four®**: April 4
- **Championship**: April 6

No specific bracket matchups, seed assignments, game results, or information about which #1 seeds advanced to the Elite Eight were recoverable from this extraction. The page appears to be a live, dynamically updated bracket tool, and the substantive bracket data was not captured in the text extraction.
</QuestionSource>

<QuestionSource url="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament">
## Summary: NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament (Wikipedia Article)

### Key Structural Facts Relevant to the Question

**Tournament Format:**
- 68 teams participate in a single-elimination format
- Four separate regions each receive a No. 1 seed (one per region)
- The Elite Eight (Regional Finals/Round of 8) is reached after winning three games in regional play
- Teams must win six total games to win the championship

**Seeding History:**
- Full seeding (1–10 per region) began in **1979**
- Since 2004, the selection committee reveals overall rankings among #1 seeds
- Since 2017, the top 16 seeds are previewed three weeks before Selection Sunday

### Historical #1 Seed Performance (Mentioned in Article Background/Question Context)
- **2025:** All four #1 seeds reached the Final Four
- **2023:** No #1 seeds reached the Elite Eight

### Broadcast & Revenue Context
- Games broadcast on CBS, TBS, TNT, and truTV through 2032
- Rights cost $891 million annually (Paramount Skydance and Warner Bros. Discovery)

### Notable Exceptions/Disruptions
- **2020:** Tournament cancelled due to COVID-19 (first-ever cancellation)
- **2021:** Held entirely in Indiana as COVID-19 precaution

---
*Note: This article is a general historical overview of the tournament and contains no specific information about the 2026 tournament or predictive data about future #1 seed performance.*
</QuestionSource>

<QuestionSource url="https://www.ncaa.com/news/basketball-men/article/2025-01-16/how-field-68-di-mens-teams-picked-march-madness-each-season">
## Summary: How the Field of 68 DI Men's Teams Is Picked for March Madness

This NCAA article explains the three-phase process by which the Division I Men's Basketball Committee selects, seeds, and places teams into the March Madness bracket each season.

---

### Phase I: Selecting 37 At-Large Teams
- The committee selects 37 at-large teams (in addition to 31 automatic conference qualifiers).
- Members submit initial ballots listing teams they believe deserve at-large bids.
- Teams receiving sufficient votes are placed on an "under-consideration board," and repeated voting rounds narrow the field until all 37 spots are filled.
- Conflict-of-interest rules require members to recuse themselves from voting on teams they represent or have family ties to.

---

### Phase II: Seeding All 68 Teams
- The committee ranks all 68 teams from strongest to weakest through repeated voting rounds.
- Metrics used include: BPI (ESPN), KenPom, KPI, NET, Strength of Record (ESPN), Torvik, Wins Above Bubble, and NCAA Statistics.
- After initial seeding, a "scrubbing" process allows teams to be moved up or down by simple-majority vote to refine accuracy.

---

### Phase III: Building the Bracket
Key bracketing principles relevant to #1 seeds include:

- **No. 1 seeds are placed first**, assigned to four separate regions. The overall No. 1 seed selects its preferred region and first/second-round site.
- The committee aims for **regional competitive balance**, preferring no more than six seed-value points separating regions.
- **Conference separation rules** prevent teams from the same conference meeting too early (e.g., teams that played 3+ times cannot meet before the Regional Final).
- Teams are kept **geographically close to their home region** when possible.
- Top-seeded teams will **not be placed where they face a significant home-crowd disadvantage**.
- A scheduling constraint ensures not all four #1 seeds are placed at Thursday/Saturday sites — the fourth is moved to a Friday/Sunday site.

---

### Committee Composition
The 12-member committee includes representatives from autonomy conferences and nonautonomy conferences, serving five-year terms. The current chair is **Keith Gill, Commissioner of the Sun Belt Conference**.

---

*Note: This article describes the selection and seeding process only — it contains no data or predictions specific to the 2026 tournament or historical #1 seed performance in the Elite Eight.*
</QuestionSource>

<QuestionSource url="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament">
## Summary: 2025 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament

### Key Outcome Relevant to the Question
**All four #1 seeds reached the Elite Eight in 2025.** The Elite Eight consisted of four #1 seeds, three #2 seeds, and one #3 seed — tied with 2007 as the lowest seed total for an Elite Eight in tournament history. All four #1 seeds then advanced to the Final Four (Florida, Duke, Houston, and Auburn), an occurrence only previously matched by the 2008 tournament.

### Tournament Context
- The 2025 tournament was notably **low on upsets**: only four total upsets occurred (three in the first round, one in the second round)
- No top-four seed lost in the first round
- All 12 games of the Sweet 16 and Elite Eight were won by the higher-seeded team
- The Sweet 16 was composed entirely of Power Four conference teams (SEC, Big Ten, Big 12, ACC) — the first time since the 1985 expansion to 64 teams

### Champion
Florida defeated Houston 65–63 in the championship game, claiming its third title and first since 2007.

### Historical Note
The article explicitly contrasts 2025's result with **2023, when no #1 seeds reached the Elite Eight**, highlighting the significant year-to-year variability in #1 seed performance.
</QuestionSource>

<QuestionSource url="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament">
## Summary: 2023 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament

### Key Outcome Relevant to the Question
**This was the first NCAA tournament in history in which all top (#1) seeds failed to make the Elite Eight.** Alabama and Houston (both #1 seeds) were eliminated in the Sweet Sixteen, making 2023 the historic low-water mark for #1 seed Elite Eight performance — **zero #1 seeds reached the Elite Eight**.

The article also notes this year had "the fewest combined 1- and 2-seeds left in the Elite Eight in tournament history, with only 2-seed Texas remaining."

### Notable Upsets Contributing to #1 Seed Failures
- **Fairleigh Dickinson defeated #1 seed Purdue** in the first round (63–58) — only the second time in history a 16-seed defeated a 1-seed
- **#15 Princeton defeated #2 seed Arizona** in the first round

### Tournament Result
- **Champion:** UConn Huskies (defeated San Diego State 76–59 in the championship game)
- **Final Four teams:** UConn, San Diego State, Florida Atlantic (9-seed), and Miami (FL) — notably, **no #1 seeds** participated in the Final Four, only the third such occurrence since the tournament expanded to 64 teams in 1985

### Historical Context Provided
- 2023 was the third Final Four without any #1 seeds since 1985 expansion (previous: 2006, 2011)
- It was the first Final Four in history without any teams seeded 1–3
</QuestionSource>
